title: 820-3787 short to ground on PP3v3_s5
message: This is a waterdamaged board with damage around the battery connector area. I get PPbus_G3h, green light on charger, PP3v3_s3 is there as well, but no _s4 power rails. PP5VS4_EN on U7501 is only 0.4 V. Also resistance to ground on PP3V3_S5 is 50 ohms measured from L7560. When i plug in the charger U1100 gets hot, so i suppose this is the culprit. Are these chips generic? or do i need one from a donor board?

title: 820-3787 short to ground on PP3v3_s5
message: Hmm, dead PCH :(. Start with replacing that first. BIOS will also need fixing if you get this board going again, but that is the least of your worries.

title: 820-3787 short to ground on PP3v3_s5
message: Hey Duke, one more question for customer expectation management, from what i understand i will need a donorboard for the U1100, reballing etc. and after that what will still need to happen to the bios?

title: 820-3787 short to ground on PP3v3_s5
message: oh and also, do i need this specific board, or are there multiple options for the donor?

title: 820-3787 short to ground on PP3v3_s5
message:
if you can find a donor with the PCH and bios still on it, that is your first best option. If not, then its lottery if you get a good one from usual places. 

Once PCH is replaced and board works, we can help you in fixing the bios.

title: 820-3787 short to ground on PP3v3_s5
message: You probably won't find a donor 3787 with a PCH still on it. Get a new PCH slap it on there and see if it works. Once it works the BIOS can fixed with a clean ME region.

title: 820-3787 short to ground on PP3v3_s5
message: I have a 3662 with the pch still on it, from a customer who did not want to continue the repair, i'll try that first.

title: 820-3787 short to ground on PP3v3_s5
message: I'm having trouble removing this chip from the motherboard with the bga machine, does anybody know the temperature needed to remove the PCH from the newer models?

title: 820-3787 short to ground on PP3v3_s5
message: The same as always, the only difference is that the motherboard is a big heat sink doing his job, just let it reach the desired temp and the chip should come out like any other...

title: 820-3787 short to ground on PP3v3_s5
message: If you have issues with removing this you need more practice. This should be quite easy and 3662 boards are not really practice material! Use some shitty MCP board for this purpose.

title: 820-3787 short to ground on PP3v3_s5
message:
[QUOTE="MaxFix, post: 23444"]I'm having trouble removing this chip from the motherboard with the bga machine, does anybody know the temperature needed to remove the PCH from the newer models?[/QUOTE]

Are you using thermocouples to see what temps you are getting top side and under BGA?

title: 820-3787 short to ground on PP3v3_s5
message: We have practiced on easier boards, and have done multiple succesful gpu replacements, that's why it was a bit surprising. I'll let it bake a bit longer before trying to remove.

title: 820-3787 short to ground on PP3v3_s5
message: A chip like this should lift in about 90 seconds. Any longer will just fry the chip and board.

title: 820-3787 short to ground on PP3v3_s5
message: So it's been a while, but we have finally received a 'new' pch from china. I slapped it on the board, and the short to ground is gone. The machine seems to respond to smc reset, but i am still not getting PP5VS4_EN, or any of the higher power rails.. does this have to do with the clean ME region that the smc needs? Or should the machine boot if everything is ok?

title: 820-3787 short to ground on PP3v3_s5
message: This could be anything from bad soldering on your "new" PCH or a dead CPU. I would not waste time on this one.
